bug.short_desc: [implementation] commitWorkingCopy() assumes file already exists

long_desc.thetext:
ICompilationUnit.commitWorkingCopy() fails if the resource does not already exist. This makes it difficult for APT to save to disk, during build, a type that was created during reconcile.
What's worse, the failure mode is that the file does get created, but in a location relative to the disk root rather than relative to the workspace.
Inside commitWorkingCopy(), the stack looks like this:
FileBuffers.getWorkspaceFileAtLocation(IPath) line: 72 FileBuffers.getFileStoreAtLocation(IPath) line: 138 JavaTextFileBuffer.commitFileBufferContent(IProgressMonitor, boolean) line: 488 JavaTextFileBuffer(JavaFileBuffer).commit(IProgressMonitor, boolean) line: 131 DocumentAdapter.save(IProgressMonitor, boolean) line: 392 CommitWorkingCopyOperation.executeOperation() line: 123 CommitWorkingCopyOperation(JavaModelOperation).run(IProgressMonitor) line: 720 Workspace.run(IWorkspaceRunnable, ISchedulingRule, int, IProgressMonitor) line: 1742 CommitWorkingCopyOperation(JavaModelOperation).runOperation(IProgressMonitor) line: 784 CompilationUnit.commitWorkingCopy(boolean, IProgressMonitor) line: 341
The FileBuffers and JavaTextFileBuffers classes come from org.eclipse.core.filebuffers. FileBuffers.getWorkspaceFileAtLocation() returns null if the file does not exist in the workspace; then getFileStoreAtLocation() returns null; and that makes commitFileBufferContent() "fall back" to writing the file relative to the disk root rather than the workspace root. For instance, it might write the type com.xyz.A to c:/foo/generated-src/com/xyz/A.java, rather than writing it to a folder under the "foo" project.
I am not sure what the correct behavior should be. It could: - throw an exception if the file does not already exist; - create the file if needed, but throw an exception if the package fragment folder does not exist; - create both the folder and the file as needed.

Guess we have to fix this since the API of commitWorkingCopy() says: *

* Since 2.1, a working copy can be created on a not-yet existing compilation * unit. In particular, such a working copy can then be committed in order to create * the corresponding compilation unit. *

A primary working copy is the one that uses the working copy owner set by JDT UI: WorkingCopyOwner.setPrimaryBufferProvider(...)
This is the one used for everything we show in the JDT UI and in the Java editor. According to the Javadoc this must also work for the primary working owner.
NOTE: make sure to call discardWorkingCopy() afterwards, otherwise we have a leak

(In reply to comment #3) > A primary working copy is the one that uses the working copy owner set by JDT > UI: > WorkingCopyOwner.setPrimaryBufferProvider(...)
In the call sequence we're using to get the working copy (shown up above), there is nothing that explicitly specifies who the owner is. I am assuming that we get the JDT UI owner by default, but I haven't chased through the code to verify that.
> make sure to call discardWorkingCopy() afterwards, otherwise we have a leak
Yes, we are being careful to track and discard every working copy we create.

Fixed in HEAD. Available in builds > N20061120-0010.
Added CompilationUnitDocumentProviderTest.testNewFile()
Problem is fixed in I20061121-1845. Thanks, Dani.
*** Bug 76746 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Set encoding for org.eclipse.wst.server.ui plugin project

long_desc.thetext: When checking out the 1.5.x maintenance branch using a UTF-8 workspace, I found that many of my plugins failed to build at all. Eventually I tracked it down to org.eclipse.wst.server.ui/serverui/org/eclipse/wst/server/ui/internal/actions/RunOnServerActionDelegate.java using the ISO8859-1 encoding and that preventing the compiler from continuing. Could a project-level default encoding be set in CVS to prevent others from running into this? One example where it is important is on Linux, where the default encoding tends to be UTF-8 instead of ISO8859-1.

David did this for most plug-ins in 1.5, but I missed that this plug-in wasn't included.
Change dropped to HEAD, will release soon.
Released. Updated wst.server.ui for 1.5.3 and all other projects for 2.0.
Closing.

bug.short_desc: Error in specifing different config.ini files for eclipse with command prompt

long_desc.thetext:
I have two config.ini files, C:\eclipse\configuration\config.ini (Default eclipse config.ini) C:\eclipse\app1\configuration\config.ini (Custom config.ini)
So I can run my eclipse with command prompt like this (to give 2nd custom config.ini to eclipse)
C:\eclipse>eclipse -configuration C:\eclipse\app1\configuration,
But above command doesnt work when there is a default config.ini file. I think eclipse first looks for default config.ini file and if it is not exists then it load custom config.ini file.
I have tested this with eclipse 3.0 and 3.2.

By default eclipse will cascade configurations over the default configuration. The custom config.ini should be read first, then the config.ini from the default configuration area. When a config.ini is read it we should *not* override any properties which are already set (using -D vm args or from the custom config.ini etc).
If you want to prevent cascading then you should set the following property in your custom config.ini
osgi.configuration.cascaded=false

Hi Yes this is not a bug, I have tested it with commenting entry of custom config.ini file that is why it load that from default location(The commented entry).
Thank you.
(In reply to comment #1) > By default eclipse will cascade configurations over the default configuration. > The custom config.ini should be read first, then the config.ini from the > default configuration area. When a config.ini is read it we should *not* > override any properties which are already set (using -D vm args or from the > custom config.ini etc). > > If you want to prevent cascading then you should set the following property in > your custom config.ini > > osgi.configuration.cascaded=false >
(In reply to comment #1) > By default eclipse will cascade configurations over the default configuration. > The custom config.ini should be read first, then the config.ini from the > default configuration area. When a config.ini is read it we should *not* > override any properties which are already set (using -D vm args or from the > custom config.ini etc). > > If you want to prevent cascading then you should set the following property in > your custom config.ini > > osgi.configuration.cascaded=false >
(In reply to comment #1) > By default eclipse will cascade configurations over the default configuration. > The custom config.ini should be read first, then the config.ini from the > default configuration area. When a config.ini is read it we should *not* > override any properties which are already set (using -D vm args or from the > custom config.ini etc). > > If you want to prevent cascading then you should set the following property in > your custom config.ini > > osgi.configuration.cascaded=false >
Thanks, closing bug.

bug.short_desc: [160975] PDCoreUtil needs to manage and create nodes using case insensitive methods

long_desc.thetext:
This is a 4.2.1.1 mirror of bug 160975.
PDCoreUtil needs to manage and create nodes using case insensitive methods since two different application services can create nodes using the same name, but different cases for the node name. IE) I can create a node called "myhost" then create another node called "MYHOST" - PDCoreUtil thinks these are two different things, when in fact they aren't. This is a simple fix - wherever the node name is checked as "equals" just use "equalsIgnoreCase" (or similar to that effect).
We find the problem when we have two application services, one using trace and another using statistical models, we get two nodes created and when data is collected in realtime, some data is dropped and is never persisted into the model. I'm not sure why this happens, but I managed to run a runtime workbench and modified PDCoreUtil to use the equalsIgnoreCase and data loss was not observed.
fix submitted to 4.2.1.1 code base.

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] common navigator loads nodes for editor before activating it

long_desc.thetext:
created a navigator extending common navigator.
1. open few editors of same type. 2. close the application 3. open the application Actual 4. Randomly editors are chosen and initialized(loading the nodes in common navigator).
Expected 5. only active editor can be initialised - require 6. other editors can be initilised only when the user selects/activates them.
This initilzation for all the opened editors makes loading time more.
Is this a link with editor bug or are you trying to double click nodes to open an editor? Can you provide more details?

Example I have 3(A,B,C) nodes, For each node we have an editor. While the user shutdown the application. He closes the A editor. He kept opened the B and C(where B is at the top in the page).
While restarting, the application keeps the B editor at the top. Still C is activated neither by application nor by the user. The problem is sub nodes for C is loaded. We need to treat A and C are equal. If either one(A or C) is opened through common navigator(or while the user clicks the C Editor tab header), the subnodes can be loaded.

When you say that the nodes are "loaded", is that because Link with Editor expanded the tree and A,B,C are peers?
Have you tried restarting without the Link with Editor (the little yellow arrows) feature turned on?

>Yes A ,B ,C are peers.

bug.short_desc: A problem in the Dataset Parameter Binding dialog [0705]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: In the "Edit data set parameter binding" dialog, value of dataset parameter is blank instead of showing the actual information.
Build Number: 2.2.0.v20061107-0635
Steps to reproduce: 1.Create a datasource and dataset, and create a dataset parameter with default value. 2.Pull the dataset to the report layout, and click on the table. Click the "Binding" tab in the "Property Editor", click the "Dataset Parameter Binding" button, you will find the value of dataset parameter is displayed correctly. Double click on one record, a "Edit data set parameter binding" dialog pops up. But the value is blank.
Expect Result: Display the actual value.
The default value set in data explorer and the value set in "Binding" tab are held by two different kinds handles. It needs a little further discussion before fixing.

Is it correct that each binding can overwrite the default value of the data set's parameter? So the data set binding UI is correct not to show any value to indicate that this binding is using the data set's parameter default value.
GUI displays and supports to edit the value in binding parameter, but the default value is not held by ParameterBindingHandle, it is held by OdaDataSetParameterHandle.

Created an attachment (id=53720) jpg file
Please see the attached jpg file.
It's convient for user to edit the value of dataset parameter if we load the default value in the "Edit dataset parameter binding" dialog. User don't care which handle that will called.
DTE use OdaDataSetParameterHandle to store default value. UI use ParamBindingHandle to store local default value. So DTE and UI should do translation about it. Back to UI. Thanks!

(In reply to comment #4) > Created an attachment (id=53720) [edit] > jpg file > Please see the attached jpg file. > It's convient for user to edit the value of dataset parameter if we load the > default value in the "Edit dataset parameter binding" dialog. User don't care > which handle that will called.
Default value has been displayed on "Dataset Parameter Binding" page. Launch the "Edit dataset parameter binding" dialog means inputting new value to override the default one.
Dataset is binding to a TABLE(or a LIST, or other element), its parameter default value should not be changed on editing the TABLE's binding. So, I think it isn't resonalbe to load default value at TABLE's side for edit, because it may make users feel that they could modify the dataset's default value at TABLE side or wherever it is binded.
See comment #6.

bug.short_desc: Fragments do not over-ride down level fragments

long_desc.thetext:
Plug-ins with the same ID in Eclipse over ride down level versions of the same plug-in. Fragments should have the same behaviour, and it is not documented otherwise in Eclipse 3.1. However, if the same fragment ID exists in Eclipse with two different version levels for some reason the lower level Fragment is displayed.
This has the implication that NL content can not be updated on locally installed ICs:
To view this problem in the base Eclipse package put the files attached in plugins.zip. Then view the help system in IC mode with browser local set to 'fr'. You will notice that all items in the Navigation Tree for the plugins will be prefixed "3.1.1" (used in fragment version 3.1.1) instead of "3.1.2" (used in fragment version 3.1.2).
Note: The only work around is to not only update the fragment version, but also the plug-in version and ensure that all fragments have match=perfect defined. This workaround is poor because it requires users to download a plug-in that is exactly the same with the exception that the plug-in version number is different. If match="perfect" is not defined on any of the installed fragments the only work around is to increase the plug-in and fragment version number so it is no longer compatible.
This is a severe limitation as it is not possible to update fragments only, which is why there are fragments in the first place.
Created an attachment (id=53536) sample plugin
Created an attachment (id=53537) screenshot
Sounds like a runtime issue.

NL fragments must be singleton bundles. The nl fragments attached here are using the old 2.1 format (only contain a plugin.xml and no bundle manifest META-INF/MANIFEST.MF file).
The compatibility plugin converter that converts old-style plugin.xml files to bundle manifests will only make the plugin/fragment a singleton if the plugin.xml file contains an extensions/extension points or uses the singlton attribute. I suggest you convert your old-style plug-ins to use OSGi manifests and specify them as singletons in the bundle manifest. (i.e. Bundle-SymbolicName: com.ibm.help.ic.doc.nl1; singleton:=true)

At runtime the compatibility plugin converter automatically generates the META-INF/MANIFEST.MF files in the configuration\org.eclipse.osgi\manifests directory for plug-ins that do not include the manifest file in the plug-in. The generated plug-in manifest file contains the text: "Bundle-SymbolicName: com.ibm.help.ic.doc; singleton:=true". The converter also automatically generates the META-INF/MANIFEST.MF files for the fragments but the "; signleton:=true" suffix is not included in the file, and I do not see why fragments should be treated differently. Would there ever be a reason not to have a fragment of a plug-in as singleton? The Eclipse 3.1 documentation does not make mention of a singleton attribute to use in plugin.xml or fragment.xml in the plugin.dtd

bug.short_desc: implement background synchronization of task data for JIRA

long_desc.thetext: This requires implementing JiraOfflineHandler.getChangeSinceLastSync
Rob, I'll need some of your guidance regarding time stamps on this one.
Need this for JIRA queries to work predictably.

I'm trying to figure a way to optimize here but without much luck. It appears we don't have the same power available to us as we do with Bugzilla queries. Although Jira queries can be limited to update date ranges the timestamp is only to the day granularity (I won't even go into the timestamp issues we face here). In addition we can't limit the query to specific issues. Is there an advance query facility I'm not aware of on Jira?
P.S. Without these advance query options we're faced with synching each task in the query.

Web UI for query allows seconds granularity for relative intervals:
--- For example, '1w 2d 5h 30m', where w = weeks, d = days, h = hours, m = minutes, If the field starts with a '-', it is treated as a time in the past, for example, '-1w 3d' is "10 days ago". An unset field denotes unbounded, so if from is blank, and to is -1d, this means "everything earlier than 1 day ago". ---
Unfortunately RelativeDateRangeFilter in JIRA core services does not allow to pass second interval (it does allow hours though). Also note that I haven't added support for relative intervals to our JIRA query wizard.
We'll have to check with Brock and Mike if there is an api for getting back details for list of ids.
Rob: can you use RelativedateRangeFilter? You don't need a granularity of seconds.
Yes, there must be a way we can use the relative date ranges, I'll see what I can do...

Done. Currently we're using the relative date capability and are unable to limit to specific tasks. Brock informed me that JIRA doesn't expose an issue key filter. If we start getting reports of slowness on background synchronization of queries we can open a new report to investigate other was to scope these filters (ie. limiting to certain products).
Created an attachment (id=54366) mylar/context/zip

Sweet!
Eugene: note that this will result in a big synch the first time it runs. I'll put a note in the New & Noteworthy.

bug.short_desc: [quick fix] Create fields from parameters

long_desc.thetext: Works for me by selecting the parameter 'name'. Moving to JDT UI to decided whether to show the quick assist inside the constructor as well.
I think the quick assist on the parameter name is good enough.

In my example, add a field "private String name;", then position the cursor on the name parameter of the constructor and use the quick fix. Now, you'll have *two* fields "name".
Can you please add a check if the field already exists and just assign the parameter in this case?
You're right. I don't know why I didn't see the second entry.

bug.short_desc: [code cleanup] Add/remove "this."

long_desc.thetext:
I'd like to propose a code cleanup which allows to remove unambiguous usages of "this." in a class or to add "this." in front of all fields to prevent these scope mistakes.
There should also a code formatter preference which allows to control if Ctrl-Space automatically prepends "this." when I complete a class field.

>There should also a code formatter preference which allows to control if >Ctrl-Space automatically prepends "this." The formatter by definition only fiddles with whitespace. This would need a new
>There should also a code formatter preference which allows to control if >Ctrl-Space automatically prepends "this." when I complete a class field. Please one bug/enhancement per request. This will be treated as request for clean up.
You're right. I've created bug 164012 for the "this." completion.

Goto: Source>Clean Up... on the 'Member Accesses' tab enable 'Use this qualifier for field accesses'. Select 'Always' if you want to generate 'this' qualifiers, select 'Only if necessary' if you want to remove them.

bug.short_desc: AbstractDecoratedTextEditor#validateEditorInputDerived(): incorrect check for 'derived' status code

long_desc.thetext:
I20061108-1600
The implementation of AbstractDecoratedTextEditor#validateEditorInputDerived() is slightly incorrect here:
if (status.getCode() != IFileBufferStatusCodes.DERIVED_FILE || (FileBuffers.PLUGIN_ID.equals(pluginId) && EditorsUI.PLUGIN_ID.equals(pluginId))) return true;
The right hand side of the || is always false, so the method would show the "derived" dialog for a status code from another plug-in, if it happens to be the same code as IFileBufferStatusCodes.DERIVED_FILE.

I believe using minimumHeight field of TreeEditor's superclass ControlEditor is not really a resolution, rather a workaround. I.e. clients of org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TreeViewerEditor can't access TreeEditor and control aspects like minimumHeigth.

bug.short_desc: Agent startup for iSeries 520 V5R3

long_desc.thetext: Hi, We are trying to profile a Java application(JRE 1.4) running on iSeries 520 V5R3 using TPTP 4.2.0. We were able to successfully start the RAServer program. We added the JVM argument for the agent in the application's startup script (-XrunpiAgent:server=enabled). However the application fails to startup. Is this a problem related to backward incompatibility of TPTP 4.2. The OS/JRE statement says that TPTP 4.2 has been tested with JRE 1.5 and iSeries V5R4. Strangely there are no service logs generated and the application log is also silent when this issue occurs.

On the iSeries you are running RAC, there is no backwards compatibility being used on that platform (only on the Windows IA32, IPF, EM64T platforms are using backwards compatibility with the new AC).
Assigning to Samson for initial investigation.

Hi. Did you add the library "HYADESDC" to your application's library list before starting up the application? The "-XrunpiAgent" is looking for the "PIAGENT" service program in the "HYADESDC" library. Without this library in the library list the JVM will fail to startup due to a failure to load the "PIAGENT" service program.

(In reply to comment #2) > Hi. Did you add the library "HYADESDC" to your application's library list > before starting up the application? The "-XrunpiAgent" is looking for the > "PIAGENT" service program in the "HYADESDC" library. Without this library in > the library list the JVM will fail to startup due to a failure to load the > "PIAGENT" service program. >
Hi sam! The HYADESDC library is in the application's library list. The problem seems to be the backward compatibility issue on iSeries. Is there any workaround for this issue as upgrading the platform to V5R4 is not possible in the near time frame for us. Thanks and Regards, Jaiganesh.

The Agent Controller binaries are built on a V5R2 iSeries machine with V5R1 compatibility compiler flag turned on (-qTGTRLS=V5R1M0). This has been tested on V5R2(520), V5R3(530) and V5R4(540).
On top of the library list, you might need to enable multithreading for you application environment. If you are running QShell, you need to do this:
export QIBM_MULTI_THREADED=Y
before starting your application. If you are staring it from CL, you will need to creaate a JOBD and enable multithreading in the JOBD.
How about the JOBLOG? Is there anything logged there?
Set the target to 4.2.1.1 for investigation purpose.
TPTP 4.2.1.1 and 4.3 are closing down so resetting target to 4.4.
Please target to future due to resources
Hi Bing. I have transferred my bugs to you for triage. Thanks.

bug.short_desc: AGR Tests with verification hooks fail in Quick Mode

long_desc.thetext:
TPTP AGR and agent controller from TPTP4.2.1 used. WindowsXP Platform
AGR tests with java verification hooks referencing a View fail in Quick mode, while they execute successfully in standard mode.
Private email sent to Ali with more details. Please contact me for more details.

The user is prompted with:
Failed to locate the context view ...

Created an attachment (id=53668) Patch
This patch is the merged fix for the following defects: 164138, 163943, 163942
Although I had difficulty reproducing this defect, I have added some code to more aggressively search for a view. The method that located a view was only using the active page to show the desired view. The attached patch will traverse through all workbench windows and pages to attempt to find the desired view. The patch makes the following change:
1) Return the view if found by the active page 2) Return the view if it can be shown by the active page 3) Return the view if it can be found by any available page of the workbench
Fix checked into HEAD stream.
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Use other attributes as the default ID for a tree item

long_desc.thetext:
While creating a UML Project, the AGR test scripts generated during the recording phase seem to depend on the position of the created UML Project in the test developers workspace in relation to the other plugins that may exist in the workspace. If the UML project is named such that it appears as the very first plugin in the development workspace while creating the tests, there seems to be no problems. However, if it such that the UML project is not the first one, then the scripts fail at the "item-expand" command.
This problem does not seem to depend on whether uses Object mine or not. Thus, failure occurs at "item-expand" command seen in the followig script snippets from two different AGR test cases doing the same task.
=================================================================== <command descriptive="TestUMLProject" type="item-expand" referenceId="24" value="true"> <item referenceId="25"/> <item referenceId="29"/> </command> =========================================
<command descriptive="TestUMLProject_1" type="item-expand" resolverId="org.eclipse.tptp.test.auto.gui.adaptive" contextId="view/org.eclipse.ui.navigator.ProjectExplorer" widgetId="{{/}}-{{1.0}}" value="true"> <item path="{{/TestUMLProject_1}}-{{1.0}}" resolverId="org.eclipse.tptp.test.auto.gui.adaptive"/> <item path="com.ab.abc.abcd.abcde.ModelFolderViewerElement5|1|"/> </command>
================================================================= Note: The path name (com.ab.abc.abcd.abcde.) has been purposely changed in the above snippet to hide details.
A more detailed email with the complete test scripts and explanation have been sent to Ali. Please contact me directly for additional information.
Priority has been set to critical because this seems to be a major problem considerably restricting the use of AGR.

Govin,
As mentioned in my response to your e-mail, by default tree item indices are used to resolve an item. The user has the option of changing that by registering their widget and providing more robust methods to use as a unique ID.
I can use this defect to change the default mechanism so that other attributes (e.g. the label of the tree item) is used to resolve a tree item.
This has been the way things have been since AGR was published in TPTP 4.1.0. I don't see any reason why 4.3 should be hold off fixing this defect. I am going to lower the severity to major and change the summary description. This will be addressed in 4.4 with priority P2.

Created an attachment (id=53659) Patch
This patch is the merged fix for the following defects: 164138, 163943, 163942
Fix checked into HEAD stream.
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.

bug.short_desc: [rulers] Cannot show annotations of old revisions of plugin.xml in quick diff mode

long_desc.thetext:
I20061108-1600
- Make sure Preferences > Team > CVS > Annotate > Use QuickDiff is set to Yes - Take org.eclipse.jdt.junit from CVS and open its plugin.xml - Go to the plugin.xml tab - Context menu > Team > Show Annotation => A new editor is opened (bug 163952)
- Now go to the History view and choose context menu > Show Annotation on an older revision => A plain text editor is opened showing the contents of the old revision, but there's no QuickDiff ruler showing annotations. Also the Annotate view does not show any information. => Expected: Should behave like when I do the same on a Java file: Open a file-specific editor with the old revision and show the annotation ruler.
For some reason, the default text editor doesn't support QuickDiff annotations when the input is not a file. Moving to Platform/Text for comment.

Quick diff is currently - per design - only for files that can be changed.
Markus, this isn't about quick diff, right? You want to see the annotations.

> Markus, this isn't about quick diff, right? You want to see the annotations.
Yes, I just want to see annotations for an old revision. But since annotations are now shown in the ruler for everything else, I think it would be most suitable to do the same for plugin.xml files.
This already works for old revisions of .java files (which can also not be changed), so I would expect that it works the same way for other files.
Talked to Markus: he wasn't thinking of quick fix but of seeing the annotations in the editor that shows the revision. This should work once bug 165945 is fixed.

Your statement is not correct. This is still an issue when text files are Annotated from either the History view or the Repositories view. In 3.2, we had two ways of showing annotations. We used QuickDiff for local files and a separate view for remote files. In 3.3, support for QuickDiff was added for remote files. I thought this support was for all text files but it appears to work only for Java files.
There are really only two solutions to this problem. Either we revert to the 3.2 behavior which will mean that all remote files, including Java files, do not use QuickDiff or we enable QuickDiff for read-only text files.
I wasn't aware that this isn't working for normal text files: I tried with a Java file and it worked and there should be no reason why it's not working for the text editor. Sounds strange.

Fixed in HEAD. Available in builds > N20061130-0010.
Verified that it works for plugin.xml.

Once I get the development guidelines written, they will state that we should not be using any internal APIs, which is a generally accepted practice anyway. Internal APIs are only used because there are no public equivalents. But bugs should be raised as we do to track the problem and hopefully influence the platform to provide public ones.

at org.eclipse.ui.forms.editor.FormEditor.createPages(FormEditor.java:142) at org.eclipse.ui.part.MultiPageEditorPart.createPartControl(MultiPageEditorPart.java:276) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchPartReference.getPart(WorkbenchPartReference.java:566) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorReference.getEditor(EditorReference.java:214) at bug.short_desc: generate API information from extension point schema definition

long_desc.thetext:
I20061108-1600
Extension point schema definition files can contain attributes of type "java" which specify that the attribute value must be the fully qualified name of a java class that is a subtype of a given API type. This information should be used to automatically generate (parts of) the "API Information" section of the description document.
E.g. the schema for org.eclipse.debug.core.launchConfigurationTypes has correctly defined requirements on the "migrationDelegate" attribute, but this information was not available in the generated doc (bug 163961).

bug.short_desc: plugin.xml editor: Open Description should open exsd file, not preview

long_desc.thetext:
I20061108-1600
When I Ctrl+Click or use "context menu > Open Description" on an extension point name in a plugin.xml editor, I only get a preview of the schema description. If the .exsd source file is available for the target extension point, then that file should be opened instead of the preview.

You already have an 'Open schema' a context menu item which opens the exsd file.
Also, The 'Schema' field on the Extensions page has a link that takes you to the .exsd file.
Description indicates the user-friendly HTML document describing the extension point. I don't agree that we should start opening .exsd files to people who expect to glance the overall description.

also, ctrl+click on a 'schema' attribute of an extension-point element opens the .exsd file, which is great.
While, ctrl+click on the 'point' attribute of an <extension> element opens the HTML description is also great, because a consumer (ie. extension) would most likely be interested in the HTML description.
Current behaviour is fine, unless I'm missing something.

I probably wasn't too clear that I meant an <extension point=...> (a reference to an extension point, not the declaration). When I e.g. open the plugin.xml of the jdt.junit plug-in, I have:
<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.views"> ...
From within the source editor, I found no way to open the exsd file for that extension point (i.e., there's no "Open Schema" context menu item). However I looked around a bit further now, and I found that the context menu of the Outline contains "Find Declaration". When I open the search result, I have the link to the schema file right in the <extension-point ... > declaration.
Needs a few clicks, but I can live with that.
oh ok. it's actually useful/easy to add 'Open Declaration' to the context menu of the selection in the source editor. This way people who have the outline view closed could benefit from the function.

This feature request is a good one. I also found it tedious to get from the extension point ID to the extension point schema in the source page.
The "Open Description" action has been left intact; but, renamed to "Show Description" to make it consistent with other instances of the action.
Fixed.
Target: 3.3 M4 Patch: patch_163967_2006-11-16_15-47
Patch released to HEAD
Work Done:
* Created a new generic / reusable open schema action -> Added to the context menu of the manifest source page only when the cursor lies within the point attribute of an extension element
* Added a new utility open schema method on the schema editor -> Open schemas given a File input
* Created an extension element point attribute detector in the manifest source editor -> Detects whether cursor is within the region occupied by a point attribute of an extension element -> Finds the corresponding schema file related to the detected extension point and sets it as input on the open schema action -> Enables / disables the open schema action based on the detection outcome
TODO:
* Add open schema action to a common action group to allow accessibility from different parts of the PDE UI -> Will open seperate bug report for that

bug.short_desc: Error message 'File system is read-only' is misleading for not supporting putInfo

long_desc.thetext:
The default implementation of FileStore's putInfo method throws an exception saying 'The file system is read-only'. This isn't a great error message to use for a file system that actually is writable. Furthermore, it's quite possible that some filing systems can't change attributes, so overriding this method shouldn't be a pre-requisite for writing files. Indeed, it's possible to have an EFS implementation that doesn't need this method to be overridden to write a new file; it only seems to get invoked when files are copied.
The workaround is simple; obey the documented contract to override this method; however, the default behaviour should be fixed to either say (a) the user hasn't implemented putInfo (rather than the filing system not being writiable, which is a lie), or (b) have this error message removed since it's not a requirement to implement this function in order to write new files.

This is the contract of the method:
* This implementation always throws an exception indicating that this file system * is read only. This method should be overridden for all writable file systems.
As it says, you must overwrite the method if you don't want that default behaviour. Too late to change the spec now.

Can you at least change the error message to something more accurate, like this file system does not support putting of file info attributes? It really has nothing to do with whether the file system is read-only or not.

Just because I'm tired of reading blog posts about it: I believe the current message is the most useful to an end user when the file system does not support writing file attributes. As a developer, a more specific message might be more useful to *you*, but this message is something that is surfaced to the end user. The end user won't be able to make sense of "this file system does not support putting of file info attributes". It's not a particularly useful distinction to the end user when a file system supports writing file data, but cannot write critical information such as the file's timestamp. The resolution of WONTFIX is not just laziness - I really just don't agree that your request is an improvement on the current implementation.

Well, I guess that Eclipse is You, and not Me.
The point is, an end user may well be able to create new files and write new files successfully on a writable file system before receiving this error message, which only shows up when copying or moving resources between folders. As a user of Eclipse, with an implementation of EFS that doesn't support this method, I can write to folders but not copy/move between them. That's why I was suggesting changing the message; it doesn't have to be changed to anything implementation-specific, but lying to the user that the file system is not writable when it is is hardly a better solution.
I'm marking this bug as VERIFIED but I think we should agree to disagree on this one; feel free to close.

bug.short_desc: MouseExit-Events on left-handside of control are always at -1,-1

long_desc.thetext: I think this makes sense. When the mouse exits, it is by definition outside of the widget so the mouse coordinates relative to the widget on the left hand side should be negative. Please reopen this bug report if I am missing something.

Well only the x-coordinate but the y not or am I wrong MouseExit events should tell me where the mouse left a control (am I wrong here?) and this is correct in all cases beside the one I outlined. You could give it a try your self. Leave the label widget on the right side and you'll get the y-coordinate set correctly.
My use case is the following. I have a shell and I need to track the event that the mouse leaves the shell to hide it. On the shell can be an arbitary amount of controls. What I currently do is to addMouseExit-Listeners to all controls and check whether a MouseExit-Event in the neat of the bounds of the shell.
The bug I'm working on is bug #163274 and the interesting code is: - https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=53481 ToolTip#hookControlListeners - https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=53554 MyToolTipPart#handleMouseExit
If you have any idea how to track that a mouse has left a shell I'm open for any suggestions the current implementation is may be because I lack some informations and I sure it could may done better.
Ok, running SWT from HEAD, I am not seeing the -1, -1. Can you confirm this?
Not 'til weekend but when I'm back home from my journey, I'll report back

AFAIK, the values during mouse exit are supposed to *always* be -1, -1. You can receive mouse exit for many reasons, not just because the mouse actually moved. For example, programmatically releasing mouse capture. If there is a bug, it's that the values aren't -1, -1 all the time.
If you want to know where the mouse is, call Display#getCursorLocation(). To make it relative to the Control, call fromDisplay() on the control.

> that the values aren't -1, -1 all the time. > If you want to know where the mouse is, call Display#getCursorLocation(). > To make it relative to the Control, call fromDisplay() on the control.
Yeah that's it! I knew I forgot something really really obvious. Thanks Randy. I think Customizable ToolTips for JFace are now on the right way.

Using Display.getCursorLocation() instead of the values in the mouse event isn't right. For example, if you are writing a scribble program and you use getCursorLocation() instead of the x and y in mouse down, then you will scribble in the wrong place. The mouse may have moved between the time it went down and the time you started drawing.
I'm pretty sure this bug was fixed in HEAD and seeing as how it WORKSFORME, I'm going to take a chance and close this bug report (again). Reopening it as necessary doesn't hurt anything.

(In reply to comment #7) > Using Display.getCursorLocation() instead of the values in the mouse event > isn't right. For example, if you are writing a scribble program and you use > getCursorLocation() instead of the x and y in mouse down, then you will > scribble in the wrong place. The mouse may have moved between the time it went > down and the time you started drawing. > > I'm pretty sure this bug was fixed in HEAD and seeing as how it WORKSFORME, I'm > going to take a chance and close this bug report (again). Reopening it as > necessary doesn't hurt anything. >
Well for me I think it doesn't matter because the only prupose for me is to get informed when the mouse leaves the ToolTip-Area. So both work for me. Thanks for the infos.

OK, maybe I was mistaken or things have gotten better. There *does* seem to always be meaningful coordinates on win32, R3.2.1. Even when releasing mouse capture on a timer. I'm not sure if that means that all platforms can provide meaningful values.
If you find platform inconsistencies and reopen, it would help to give more background about the use case.
I think we may have fixed a bug around 3.0 in this area and you are remembering it.

Steve to you have some more insights on MouseExit events for me I tested it a bit and on win32 it seems the event occurrs in an range of 5px on the left and upper side the event coordinates are always out-side the widget whereas on the right and bottom they may occurr inside the widget. On MacOSX the behaviour seems to be different at least as Kim stated yesterday on IRC.
The test case I'm evaluating is found in bug #164351.
Might I guess that you have the BORDER style enabled?
yes. that's the difference which doesn't harm on MacOSX it seems but on win32 you are right removing the border fixes the coordinate.

The mouse has exited a control when it is no longer in the client area.
We have no control over when the operating system decides to report mouse enter or exit, however, the difference on Windows seems wierd. Internally, Windows uses a timer to detect mouse exit and this should not be affected by which side of the control the mouse exits. I'll play a bit to see what is going on.
GTK and Motif use X events for mouse enter/exit. The Mac uses a diffing strategy in the event loop to determine when the mouse under the widget changes. The diffing strategy should ignore the border (but apparently does not).

bug.short_desc: Task view doesn't sort tasks properly

long_desc.thetext: I try to sort the tasks by description, but they aren't being properly sorted. Only the folder names are sorted... not the task descriptions themselves.
What kind of tasks are you sorting? Are those just local tasks or you have query? For the latter, we'll need to know what connector this query came from.

They are bugzilla tasks from a query, but I don't really know why that should matter, unless the sorter sorts by task types, I suppose. I really just want to sort by the description text.
The problem seems to be that the view doesn't sort tasks that are children of a query.

I can't reproduce this, and when not in "Focus on Workweek" mode tasks sort properly for me. For 1.0 and at least for a while thereafter the plan is to keep things simple by only offering two kinds of sorting mode: the 'smart' interest-based sorting of the focused mode, and the manual sorting when not in this mode. This will encourage us to continue improving the interest-based sorting (e.g. bug 161626).
In 0.9 the makes this explicit by popping up a dialog that indicates that the sort order will not be applied until the focused mode is disabled, if enabled.

bug.short_desc: Problems with large log support on Linux

When a database is generated using the TPTP script files, the database name is set to "HYADES". The connection to the database on Linux will fail because it is actually looking for a database with the name "Hyades".
The workaround is to simply rename the folder name from "HYADES" to "Hyades". The same problem is not experienced on Windows because of not being case sensitive.

Fixed.

bug.short_desc: xmlns default value wrong when creating new VXML File

long_desc.thetext:
Default xmlns attribute value not correct. The value is currently "http://www/w3/org/2001/vxml" but should be "http://www.w3.org/2001/vxml". I have found the problem in NewFileContentGenerator.java, method writeNamespaceAttribute.
org.eclipse.vtp.editor-->src-->org.eclipse.vtp.editor.internal.wizards-->NewFileContentGenerator.java-->writeNamespaceAttribute()
This method (in version 1.1 of the class) has the following: String namespace = "http://www/w3/org/2001/vxml"; //$NON-NLS-1$
It should be: String namespace = "http://www.w3.org/2001/vxml"; //$NON-NLS-1$
Thanks, Stan Rivera

bug.short_desc: [search] no results from SearchEngine.searchAllTypeNames with types in scope

It seems changes to the open type dialog, are causing items passed in to the dialog as part of a search scope to not be shown.
for example: if you have a package with 5 classes in it and each of those classes has a main method in it, and you then right-click on the package and select Run As -> Java Application, the dialog appears empty.
This used to work, and would display all of the classes that contain main methods in them. This also affects the launch dialog on the main tab for Java applications, where you can no longer search for main methods within the associated project.
In each case we are collecting the correct set of IJavaElements, passing them in to the dialog using the JavaUI.createTypeDialog(..) as an IJavaSearchScope, and nothing appears anymore.....

It seems that the search engine doesn't report any result. We switched to use the new API that uses a TypeNameMatchRequestor.
- set a breakpoint in SearchEngine.searchAllTypeNames(char[], int, char[], int, int, IJavaSearchScope, TypeNameMatchRequestor, int, IProgressMonitor) and org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.dialogs.TypeInfoViewer.SearchRequestor.acceptTypeNameMatch(TypeNameMatch)

bug.short_desc: XML outline expects DND data too early

long_desc.thetext:
When dragging and dropping within the XML editor's Outline view on Linux, multiple error dialogs with this (or similar) stack trace are opened:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.jface 4 2 2006-11-07 16:44:49.201 !MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.jface". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException at java.lang.String.<init>(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.common.ui.internal.dnd.ObjectTransfer.nativeToJava(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.common.ui.internal.dnd.ViewerDropAdapter.getDragSource(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.common.ui.internal.dnd.ViewerDropAdapter.helper(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.common.ui.internal.dnd.ViewerDropAdapter.dragOver(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.xml.ui.views.contentoutline.XMLContentOutlineConfiguration$2.dragOver(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.jface.util.DelegatingDropAdapter$2.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.JFaceUtil$1.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.jface.util.SafeRunnable.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.jface.util.DelegatingDropAdapter.dragOver(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.dnd.DNDListener.handleEvent(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.notifyListeners(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.dnd.DropTarget$3.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.timerProc(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS._g_main_context_iteration(Native Method) at org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.g_main_context_iteration(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runUI(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.createAndRunWorkbench(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.ui.PlatformUI.createAndRunWorkbench(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.IDEApplication.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(Unknown Source) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Unknown Source)
The ObjectTransfer class is witent to store a byte array representing a system timestamp as the actual data being dragged. It then uses that timestamp to ensure that the correct Java object, which is kept as a field, can be retrieved as part of the drop. This class is essentially the same as EMF's LocalTransfer, it's meant to provide the exact Java object on the drop, not merely an identical one. The trace being shown is supposed to retrieve that Java object before the drop has occurred, in fact before dragSetData() has been called on the drag source listener. SWT states that the DND data can be retrieved before the drop actually occurs, but only on certain platforms. Linux is not one of them, it retrieves a null value instead of any byte array and triggers a NPE when creating a String from it. The fallout from this is that each dragOver event that gets queued before the first SafeRunner catches this exception throws up a dialog. This ends up looking much like an infinite loop the end user, even though it isn't.
Two problems exist here, first that ObjectTransfer doesn't bother to check if the Java object field is not null before interacting with the native parts. If the object is null, the javaToNative method was never called and there's no relevant information in the TransferData--no timestamp to compare against. Second, that the outline view's use of a JFace DelegatingDropAdapter doesn't mesh well with the XMLDragAndDropManager/ViewerDropAdapter implementing most of the drop behavior. In part, the drag and drop manager is expecting to get a value back from the ObjectTransfer earlier than is possible on Linux. Adding the null check, while preventing the error dialogs, also seems to prevent it from correctly setting up the command to execute when the drop occurs--DND stops working on both platforms.
Part of the design of the XML editor's outline view uses the the DelegatingDropAdapter and a list of TransferDropTargetListeners that adopters can extend. Given that this is API, the best solution is to replace the calls to the XMLDragAndDropManager with equivalents that allow both for the null check within ObjectTransfer and still permits extension via the DelegatingDropAdapter.
Note that this also affects the XML Editor's Design page and the DTD editor's Outline view, as they both use variants of the XMLDragAndDropManager and ObjectTransfer type.
Created an attachment (id=53558) proposed patch
Targetting 1.5.3, as it's a very ugly and visible problem on Linux.
CCing Amy for review, although I expect it may take some time for a patch this large.

After applying the patch, I was unable to DND objects in the outline view. For example, trying to rearrange TD tags inside a table did not work. I also could not DND elements in the XML design page either. (I was on windows xp)
Strangely, the dragSetData() method on the delegating drag adapter isn't called on Windows in this case. I know it's called consistently elsewhere, so I'll have to do more digging.

Created an attachment (id=57487) updated patch, uses JFace LocalSelectionTransfer instead
Updated patch. This one works on both platforms and should work fine on Mac as well.

Dragging and dropping in outline view looks good now with the updated patch.
Dragging and dropping in the xml design page looks okay for the most part, but I found 2 regressions: 1. I am unable to drag an attribute from 1 element and drop it between attributes of another element. However, dropping the attribute on top of the other element will correctly move the attribute.
2. Sometimes, when I drag an element and drop it between 2 elements, it'll end up being the child of one of those elements rather than a sibling. I think it depends on if my cursor position is slightly above the intended drop location or not. The drop indicator looks the same (a line is drawn between the 2 elements), but the actual dropped location is different.

Created an attachment (id=57552) updated patch addressing those two issues
The height passed into the DragNodeCommand was faked using the feedback's value, but the height really does need to be recomputed for this kind of precise behavior.
Ok, those 2 issues appear fixed in the latest patch!
Releasing for candidate respin.
Verified on M200702072117

attachment.desc: updated patch, uses JFace LocalSelectionTransfer instead
updated patch addressing those two issues

bug.short_desc: Race condition in ResourceLoaderFactory

long_desc.thetext:
Hi, I'm trying to invoke a generator from my ui. And sometimes I get a generator.aow not found, and after repeating the same code it works fine. This problem occours more often on my dual-core pc than on my single-core notebook. From what I could see it happens that the generator gets a ResourceLoader from ResourceLoaderFactory that is a EclipseResourceLoaderImpl with a cl from the XTextPlugin. In those cases where it worked the code was invoked on a different Worker Thread then before where it failed.
Karsten
I figured out that it works as expected if you start the WorkflowRunner in a new Thread Object instead of a Job. But this is just a workaround and in my eyes not a solution.
Is there any chance to really reproduce this?

Is this really oAW's problem? The WorkflowRunner is normally run within its own VM instance, using a LaunchConfiguration. It seems that you run the WorkflowRunner within a plugin, am I right? However, we do not have influence on Eclipse's ResourceLoader. But you can write your own that won't fail. It can be registered by ResourceLoaderFactory.setCurrentThreadResourceLoader(resourceLoader); before executing the workflow.
I close this issue since we won't be able to reproduce it. I work also on a dual core machine and do not expect problems.

You are right that there are no race conditions if it is run in a sperte VM. But how should I be able to report errors during the run to the user in a convinence way? Or even progress? Just showing the (filtered) stdout is not enough for me. I want to have the Issue Objects and ProgressMonitor. ResourceLoaderFactory.setCurrentThreadResourceLoader(resourceLoader); does not help in this case. The Problem with it is that it attaches the resourceLoader to a Thread, and if the Thread already has one attached it does nothing. The first thing that I tried is to run it from WorkspaceJob as this seemed quite logical to me. But WorkspaceJob has a pool of Threads. And thus makes it quite unpredictable. Even creating a new Thread Object as I stated before just helps once. After the workflow once ran in this Thread it works there for ever in most cases. The real solution to this problem was archived by using https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=168123 With this bug it is possible to attach the right ClassLoaders to the ResourceLoader for any newly created Thread.
Here is the code I'm currently using: http://svn.kbsvn.net/svn/team16/trunk/statmachine.dsl.editor/src/net/kbsvn/sm/editor/actions/GenerateCodeAction.java http://svn.kbsvn.net/svn/team16/trunk/statmachine.dsl.editor/src/net/kbsvn/sm/editor/actions/StateMachineWorkflowRunner.java This is my ResourceLoader: http://svn.kbsvn.net/svn/team16/trunk/statmachine.dsl/src/net/kbsvn/sm/parser/EclipseResourceLoaderImpl.java I'm not exactly happy with this solution. But at least it works now.

Rerun manual test > When restarting the RAC on Linux, do you still have your workbench up and > running? If that's the case, you will need to restart your workbench as well > since the execution framework is caching the connection.

So I assume you have regenerated the certificate and keystore by rerunning SetConfig.

(In reply to comment #9)
Let me retry with a new install.

(In reply to comment #10) > (In reply to comment #9) > Let me retry with a new install.
Using a new install (including configuration and workspace) of both the workbench and Agent Controller (including new key store and sample certificate) and the steps in comment #3, the same symptoms are seen. Interestingly, it only appears to be a problem on the second restart/rerun (third and subsequent restarts/reruns work fine). You need to set the following environment:
LIBPATH=/home/ractest/rac/lib:$LIBPATH PATH=/home/ractest/rac/bin:/home/ractest/IBM_JRE_V1.5.0_SR_3/jre/bin:$PATH MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME=/usr/lib/mozilla LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

bug.short_desc: [RSS] feeds should use version instead of branch and branch instead of cvsbranch

long_desc.thetext:
Suggested by Hubert and discussed on cross-project-issues-dev@eclipse.org, I'm thinking of changing from using attributes "branch" and "cvsbranch" to "version" and "branch", respectively.
<build branch="2.2.2" cvsbranch="R2_2_maintenance"/>
becomes:
<build version="2.2.2" branch="R2_2_maintenance"/>
This is to be done for two reasons.
a) 2.2.2 is not a branch, it's a version. b) some projects use subversion or other source repos, so "cvsbranch" is deceptive when the backend is not CVS.
Please offer votes/comments here. I'll assume silence means it's safe to make this change, and will update this bug when the changes are in the releng_test branch of basebuilder.
+1 Looks like a good idea to me.
I don't have any problems with this change either. I'm generating rss feeds for our I-Builds but haven't had time to change to the latest schema.

OK, I think that's a quorum. AFAIK, platform, europa, and emf/uml2/emft are the only projects currently publishing feeds, with TPTP coming soon (and as this was his suggestion, I'm sure Hubert will be cool with this one.)
I'll try to get this changed ASAP.
Fixed in releng_test branch, tag v20061114.

bug.short_desc: Usability issues with Web project wizard

long_desc.thetext:
Usability issues with Web project wizard:
1) The Web project wizard sets the "Finish" button as the default button. This makes it difficult for the end user to use the keyboard to navigate thru all the wizard pages. As soon as they hit "Enter" the wizard will finish. It seems better to make "Next" the default button... this would make filling out information in all the wizard pages more natural. With the current behavior, the user has to manually tab to the "Next" button inorder to get to the next page. If it is not possible to make the "Next" button the default, perhaps a method could be provided so that wizard developers can have some control in setting the wizard default button.
2) When the user goes from one wizard page to the next, it would be nice to be able to set the focus to a specific widget on that wizard page. With the current behavior, the focus seems to be set randomly so the user has to tab to the desired widget before they can start typing information. Can there be a method added to accomplish this?
